text.headline: Ontario: "Ventilation not ventilators"
text.text: "Dear Hon. Christine Elliott, Dr. David Williams and Dr. Brian Schwartz: We urge you to update the Province’s COVID-19 guidelines, regulations and public communication to reflect the importance of ventilation and to better align with the Public Health Agency of Canada’s recent acknowledgment of aerosol transmission"

text.headline: Ontario: "Nurses Association to Doug Ford"
text.text:
"Nurses and health-care professionals expect urgent and decisive action — that you and the government
immediately update your directives and guidance to mandate precautions for airborne transmission, including
the use of N95 respirators for all nurses and health-care professionals who come into contact with any
suspected or positive COVID-19 patients, residents or clients."

text.headline: Australia: Dear Mr Hunt (Minister for Health and Aged Care)
text.text: "Australia must take urgent coordinated national action on aerosol transmission of COVID-19" - by Health Care Workers Australia

media.link: /media/letters/2021-02-15-Immediate Action to Address Inhalation Exposure to SARS-CoV-2_FINAL.pdf

text.headline: USA: Dear Mr. Zients, Dr. Walensky and Dr. Fauci
text.text:
"We write as physicians and scientists with expertise in aerosol science, occupational health and infectious
disease to commend the Biden Administration’s National Strategy for the COVID-19 Response and Pandemic

Preparedness and to urge strong immediate action to strengthen measures to limit inhalation exposure to SARS-
COV-2 as a cornerstone of this plan."

text.headline: UK: Dear Prime Minister
text.text: "The current UK Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) guidance which leads and determines the selection and use of PPE across the UK does not accurately depict the airborne risks when sharing health and care settings including working in patients’ homes and public buildings. Neither does it adequately align and convey the importance of ventilation and, more widely, engineering controls in relation to Health and Safety Executive guidance."

text.headline: Canada Air Transmission - follow up Letter
text.text: The science is clear: Protective measures must fully account for aerosol transmission of the virus, as we said in January.

media.link: /media/letters/2021_03_01_US has Manufacturing Capacity to Provide High-Filtration Masks to Every American.pdf

text.headline: The USA has the Manufacturing Capacity to Provide High-Filtration Masks to Every American
text.text: [..] "We want to assure you that America’s mask manufacturers have ample capacity to meet the entire needs of our nation during emergencies such as this pandemic. As good partners of the administration, our capacity can also serve as the foundation for future emergency response."

text.headline: Member of the US Congress - calling the CDC and OSHA to action
text.text: "[The] CDC and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) should delineate the recommended measures that need to be taken to prevent aerosol exposure—especially in workplaces. These include control measures that limit concentrations of the virus in the air, such as through better ventilation and air filtration, limiting the number of people and the time people spend in the workplace, and providing effective respiratory protection for workers with prolonged exposures or close contact with other workers, patients, or the public."

text.headline: USA: Association of the Nonwoven Fabrics Industry (INDA) - we have capacity too
text.text: Excerpt - INDA is supports the recommendations contained in the February 15 letter sent by America’s Physicians and Scientists to the Administration titled “Re: Immediate Action is Needed to Address SARS‐CoV‐2 Inhalation Exposure.” - and outlines their willingness to be the supply chain for PPE
